query: What is the core problem addressed by this paper regarding robot policy evaluation?
How does the proposed framework enable accurate real-to-sim robot policy evaluation?
How are realistic soft-body interactions simulated within the proposed framework?
What rendering technique is used to achieve photorealistic simulation, and how is it enhanced?
What types of deformable manipulation tasks and policies were used to validate the framework?
What is the main finding regarding the correlation between simulated and real-world policy performance?
How are soft-body digital twins constructed and integrated into the simulation environment?
How does this work specifically address and narrow the traditional sim-to-real gap?
How does this framework compare to prior simulation evaluation methods like SIMPLER or Real-is-sim?
What are the implications and guidance offered for future simulation-based policy evaluation pipelines?
